source.499a6730:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
%matplotlib inline
source.e33fefb8:
#Converting the CSV file into Pandas Dataframe
import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))
data = pd.read_csv("/kaggle/input/countries-of-the-world/Countries.csv")
data.head()
source.c0ad720c: data.isna().sum() #Calculating the number of 'na' values in each rows.
source.2e1fd431:
data = data.dropna() #To get the tidy data, we have dropped the rows having 'na' values
data.info()
source.79e96dbc:
sns.scatterplot(x ='Industry',y ='Service', data = data)# x and y variable defines the inputs for each axis
plt.title("Services vs Industry")#defines the title for the plot
plt.xlabel("Industry")#defines the label for x axis
plt.ylabel("Service")#defines the label for y axis
plt.show()#shows the plot
source.09709289:
sns.lineplot(x ='Industry',y ='Service', data = data)
plt.title("Services vs Industry")
plt.xlabel("Industry")
plt.ylabel("Service")
plt.show()
source.51902098:
sns.distplot(data["Phones"],bins=10,kde=False)# bins set the number of bins we want
#setting kde parameter to true will plot the line of kernel density estimates
plt.show()
source.e1762cf2:
sns.distplot(data["Phones"],hist=False,kde=True)#here the histogram bins are disabled by setting the hist element to false.
plt.show()
source.87e2cb40:
sns.distplot(data["Phones"],hist=False,rug=True,kde=True)# A rug plot is for a aingle quantitative variable.It is a one-dimensional scatter plot analogous to a histogram with zero-width bins.
plt.show()
source.2f710f6e:
sns.distplot(data["Phones"],hist=True,rug=True,kde=True)#here the histogram bins are disabled by setting the hist element to false.
plt.show()
source.25a099e3:
sns.relplot(x="Agriculture", y="Crops", data = data, kind='scatter')
plt.show()
sns.relplot(x="Agriculture", y="Crops", data = data, kind='line')
plt.show()
source.e8574949:
sns.relplot(x="Agriculture", y="Crops", data = data, kind='scatter', col='Climate', col_order=[1,1.5,2,2.5,3,4], col_wrap=3)
plt.show()
source.5794d29e:
sns.relplot(x="Agriculture", y="Crops", data = data, kind='scatter', row='Climate', row_order=[1,1.5,2])
plt.show()
source.92c49555:
sns.pairplot(data, vars=['GDP','Literacy','Agriculture'],hue='Region',palette='PuRd')#hue will be third variable to categorize the plot.
#palette sets the color of the plots
plt.show()
source.e806957f:
sns.heatmap(data.corr(),cbar=True)# corr() is the function that correlates the quantitative variables
#color bar on the right of heatmap can be enabled by setting true for cbar
plt.show()
source.6895a643:
df=pd.DataFrame()
df['Literacy']=data['Literacy']
df['Phones']=data['Phones']
df['GDP']=data['GDP']
sns.heatmap(df.corr(),annot=True,fmt="f",cbar=False,cmap="YlGnBu",linewidth=1)#defining cmap can change the colours to our desired colours.
#linewidth is the gape between each squares
#setting annot as True will show the correlation values in the heatmap
#fmt changes the format of annotations as integer,float,etc
plt.show()
source.bf70aec8:
sns.stripplot(x='Climate',y='Crops', data=data)
plt.show()
sns.stripplot(x='Climate',y='Crops', data=data,jitter=True)
plt.show()
source.1a96aa0d:
sns.barplot(x='Climate',y='Agriculture', data=data)
plt.show()
sns.barplot(x='Climate',y='Agriculture', data=data,ci=None)#setting ci as None will disable showing the confidence intervals
plt.show()
source.13b27ff7:
sns.countplot(x='Climate', data=data,order=[4,1.5,1,3,2])#order defines the order of the representation
plt.show()
source.2ab7ecd8:
sns.countplot(x='Region',data=data)
plt.xticks(rotation=270)#rotation element sets the angle of ticks
source.902a772e:
sns.catplot(x='Climate',y='Crops', data=data, kind='box',whis=1)
plt.show()
sns.catplot(x='Climate',y='Crops', data=data, kind='violin')
plt.show()
sns.catplot(x='Climate',y='Crops', data=data, kind='point')
plt.show()
source.a985d957:
#Adding a third variable in categorical plot
sns.set_style('darkgrid')
hue_colors =sns.color_palette('Blues',5)
sns.countplot(x="Region", data =data, hue='Climate',hue_order=[1,1.5,2,3,4],palette=hue_colors)
plt.xlabel("Regions")
plt.ylabel("Count")
plt.title("The counts of every Region")
plt.xticks(rotation = 270)
plt.show()

sns.color_palette("Paired")
sns.scatterplot(x ='Industry',y ='Service', data = data,hue='GDP')
plt.show()

sns.lineplot(x ='Industry',y ='Service', data = data,hue='GDP')
plt.show()
source.e80fc95e:
for style in ['white','dark','whitegrid','darkgrid','ticks']:
    sns.set_style(style)
    hue_colors =sns.color_palette('Blues',5)
    sns.countplot(x="Region", data =data, hue='Climate',hue_order=[1,1.5,2,3,4],palette=hue_colors)
    plt.xlabel("Regions")
    plt.ylabel("Count")
    plt.title("The counts of every Region")
    plt.xticks(rotation = 270)
    plt.show()
source.7bf76578:
sns.set(color_codes=True)#this will set the functionality to use matplotlib color codes
sns.countplot(x=data['Climate'], color='c')#c is for cyan
plt.show()
sns.countplot(x=data['Climate'], color='m')#m is for magenta
plt.show()
source.d4087206:
#this will show the color palettes available in seaborn
for p in sns.palettes.SEABORN_PALETTES:
    sns.set_palette(p)
    sns.palplot(sns.color_palette())
    plt.title(str(p))
    plt.show()
source.819ad48a:
sns.color_palette("Paired")#for unordered observations
sns.scatterplot(x ='Industry',y ='Service', data = data,hue='GDP')
plt.show()
source.6699c542:
sns.countplot(x='Climate', data=data,order=[1,1.5,4,3,2],palette='icefire')#for diverging patterns
#icefire is one of the diverging color pattern available in seaborn
plt.show()
